docs.lead_paragraph: As the Senate geared up for its first full weekend of debate on the health care legislation, lawmakers made plans to break from the rituals of governing to allow time for the rituals of religion. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut and an observant Jew, was prepared to vote on Saturday, the Jewish Sabbath, following his longtime custom when it comes to important issues, said a spokesman, Marshall Wittmann. Mr. Lieberman would walk to the Capitol, not drive.
docs.abstract: Senate is gearing up for its first full weekend of debate on health care legislation, but some lawmakers are making plans to break from rituals of governing to allow time for rituals of religion (S)
docs.snippet: As the Senate geared up for its first full weekend of debate on the health care legislation, lawmakers made plans to break from the rituals of governing to allow time for the rituals of religion.     Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of...

docs.lead_paragraph: As they are across the nation, Medicare patients and nurses in Maine are anxiously following the health care debate because its outcome could affect Medicare's popular home health benefit in a big way.

headline.main: A Threat to Home Health Services

docs.snippet: As they are across the nation, Medicare patients and nurses in Maine are anxiously following the health care debate because its outcome could affect Medicare's popular home health benefit in a big way.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats on Friday began the first tactical maneuvering in what is likely to be a big floor fight over a proposed government-run insurance plan, or public option.

headline.main: Tactical Maneuvering on the Public Option

docs.abstract: A few Democrats, as a tactical maneuver on the public option, ask to join a Republican amendment that would force Congress to take insurance from the new plan it creates.
docs.snippet: A few Democrats, as a tactical maneuver on the public option, ask to join a Republican amendment that would force Congress to take insurance from the new plan it creates.

docs.lead_paragraph: "Ask an Expert" is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you'll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.
docs.abstract: Andrew Stettner, deputy director of the National Employment Law Project, answers reader questions about unemployment benefits.
docs.snippet: Andrew Stettner, deputy director of the National Employment Law Project, answers reader questions about unemployment benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Senate debate over the major health care legislation resumes, the focus Friday will be on proposed reductions to Medicare Advantage, the privately administered plans that provide enhanced benefits but now typically cost the federal government more than traditional Medicare.
docs.abstract: A Senate Republican amendment to protect Medicare Advantage plans is up for debate Friday.
docs.snippet: A Senate Republican amendment to protect Medicare Advantage plans is up for debate Friday.

docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: The latest on the estate tax, why so many loan modifications stay temporary and other consumer-focused items from today's Times.
docs.snippet: The latest on the estate tax, why so many loan modifications stay temporary and other consumer-focused items from today's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate dipped slightly in November to 10 percent, from a high of 10.2 percent during the month before, according to the monthly jobs loss report issued by the Labor Department.

headline.main: The Early Word: Unemployment Rate Dips

docs.abstract: The jobless rate retreats to 10 percent for November from the 10.2 percent high in October.
docs.snippet: The jobless rate retreats to 10 percent for November from the 10.2 percent high in October.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.In August 2005, I wrote an op-ed article about war for The Washington Post that was inspired by our debate on health policy.

headline.main: Paying for Health Care (and War, by the Way)

docs.abstract: An economist on the moral hazard of not asking taxpayers to bear the cost of war.
docs.snippet: An economist on the moral hazard of not asking taxpayers to bear the cost of war.

docs.lead_paragraph: No matter what legislators are fighting about on the Senate floor, there are two issues in the health care debate that likely are key to the final outcome: provisions related to insurance coverage for abortion and to a proposed government-run health insurance plan, or public option.

headline.main: Two Issues Key to the Health Care Debate

docs.abstract: Despite the hullabaloo, the two issues that matter most in the Senate debate have not yet reached the floor: abortion and the public option.
docs.snippet: Despite the hullabaloo, the two issues that matter most in the Senate debate have not yet reached the floor: abortion and the public option.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though the American Medical Association offered qualified support for the Senate health care bill this week, many other medical groups are unqualified in their opposition.
docs.snippet: Even though the American Medical Association offered qualified support for the Senate health care bill this week, many other medical groups are unqualified in their opposition.
